intro: Rubus buergeri var. pseudobuergeri, commonly known as the Japanese blackberry, is a variant of the Rubus genus native to East Asia. It is a shrub that typically grows to a height of 1–2 meters, featuring thorny stems and trifoliate leaves. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits that are typically red or black when ripe, similar to other Rubus species. It thrives in temperate climates and is often found in moist, shaded environments. Due to its ornamental value and edible fruits, it is cultivated in gardens and for commercial use.
